SASKATCHEWAN ARCHIVES QUESTIONNAIRE

No. 2

PIONEER EXPERIENCES: A GENERAL QUESTIONNAIRE

1. Your full name: Jacob D. Stratyshuk.

2. Your address: Lumsden, Sask.

3. Date: April 21, 1952

4. Where were you born? (Give name of place and country): Western Ukraine

5. What was your father's name and occupation?: Dmytro Stratyshuk, Farmer

6. When did you come to Saskatchewan? (Give month and year): May 1902

7. Mention any other places where you lived before coming to Saskatchewan, giving dates wherever possible: Western Ukraine

8. How old were you when you first came to Western Canada? (You do not need to answer this question if you would rather not or you may use "I was a small child", "I was in my teens", etc.):

   12 years old.

9. What were your reasons for coming West?

   My parents came to Canada to seek a better living and brought all the family. Four boys (including me).

10. How did you learn about the West? (Through other people? Reading about it? Railroad or government information?):

    My uncle Hnat came to Canada in 1896, stayed here 3 years, went back to Ukraine (Old Austria), took his family back to Canada in 1900. We heard about Canada from him and my folks decided to come to Canada.
Jacob D. Stratyshuk

11. What did your friends and relatives think of your decision to come to Western Canada?
Some of them were anxious to come along too but due to poor circumstances they could not.

12. Did you travel by yourself or with a party (family, friends or other group)?
Family and party of about 50 from our village and neighboring villages.

13. What means of transportation did you use?
Steamship - Train

14. What incidents of the journey best do you remember? (People you met on the way, meetings with Indians, adventures on the journey, accidents or other excitement etc.)
In Quebec, were we landed, we were met by very good people. We did not understand their language, but from their actions we knew they were good. In Delisle we stayed in Immigration Hall during Easter Sunday. We received many gifts from local people although there were not very many of them.

15. Where did you first stay when you arrived in Saskatchewan?
Yorkton, in the Immigration Hall which was located one block south of C.P.R. Station.

16. Where did you settle or take up land?
30 miles north of Yorkton.

17. Mention any other places where you have lived since coming to Saskatchewan.
All my life I lived in Eastern Scotia, in Canada district or in town.

Was just a school boy.

19. How often did you write to relatives or friends in your old home?

Before 2nd war. I used to write to my cousins in western Ukraine (under Poland) twice a year or three times, but not every 1939.

20. If you got married, give the name of your husband or wife along with the date and place of marriage.

Mary Ochitwa July 15, 1912.

21. Did anyone else come to Saskatchewan because of your recommending it as a place to settle?

Yes, many people from our village came to Canada as a result of our letters back to the old country.

22. If other members of your family (brothers, sisters, parents, etc.) came West tell when they came and where they settled.

All came at the same time, and all stayed on the farm until they grew up.

23. Is there any particular experience of pioneer days that stands out in your memory which you would like to record?

In 1907, I and one brother together with two cousins we started in the spring to look for jobs. We walked to Winnipeg and as there was a strike on the Railroads we could not get jobs. As we knew no money other than between us, we used to buy 4 fresh loaves of rye bread for 10¢ and that was all our meal for 24 hrs. We slept by the river bank. After money was down to 50¢ I started home on the old immigrant ticket to Yorkton which was given me by a fellow country man who

Has no intention to go to Yorkton. But intended to stay in Winnipeg. I got home to Yorkton safely the next morning, walked 30 miles home, told my dad what happened. Dad sold a calf and sent $10 to my brother in Winnipeg in order to get him home.

J. D. Stratychuk Retires

Jacob D. Stratychuk, "J.-D.", a member of the staff of the Canora branch of the Canadian Bank of Commerce for 27 years, retired this month after a total of 35 years of banking.

Mr. Stratychuk was born in Western Ukraine in 1891. In 1902 he came to Canada and settled with his father on a farm, seven miles south west of Canora. The nearest post office at that time was Yorkton.

At the age of 15 he started working as a section man on the railway at 20c an hour for ten hours a day and six days a week. Two years later he took up a homestead north of Buchanan. In the fall of 1910 he broke his arm and being unable to work he attended the Regina Training school especially organized by the government for those not having had the opportunity to learn English. After 14 months he obtained his grade 10 diploma and in 1911 he started teaching school. Mr. Stratychuk taught at Dnister, Poplar Springs, Vasloutz, Mazeppa, and East Wexford. He took grade 11 by correspondence.

In 1912 Mr. Stratychuk married Mary Ochitwa and they have three daughters; Helen (Mrs. J. Hunchak), Canora; Grace (Mrs. S. T. Shabbits), Yorkton; and Zoria (Mrs. J. Lysyshyn), Canora.

On October 21, 1916 Mr. Stratychuk joined the staff of the Canadian Bank of Commerce at Canora as a discount clerk. On Feb 1, 1917 he was promoted to teller and in 1921 became assistant accountant. From 1927 to 1931 he was accountant at the Kamsack branch. When the branch closed there he was made special representative of the Bank of Commerce for eastern Saskatchewan and served in this capacity while residing at Kamsack until 1935 when he returned to Canora as accountant, the position he held until his retirement which became effective on Monday, March 5.

Mr. Stratychuk has been receiving manager at several points including Norquay, Watson, Wadena, Buchanan and Yorkton. Mr. Stratychuk has been treasurer of the Greek Catholic Parish of St. Peter and St. Paul at Canora since its inception in 1932. He was first Dominion president of the Ukrainian Catholic Brotherhood, a position which he held from 1933 to 1942. He is president of the Ukrainian Catholic Mutual Benefit Association, Canora Branch, and a Saskatchewan director.

Mr. Stratychuk plays golf and has been curling since 1912 when he was a member of the "J. D." rink which consisted of J. D. Robertson, skip, John Spandier, J. D. Reese, and J. D. Stratychuk.

Mr. and Mrs. Stratychuk intend to live in Canora where they recently built a house. Mr. Stratychuk says it will keep him busy finishing it off and fixing up the grounds—at least for some time. Later on he will probably take some part time jobs. He seems to have no intention of really "retiring" and has been considering another full-time job. Anyway to pass the time he has his work shop in the basement and has already been turning out some work since he left the bank.

Mr. Stratychuk told The Courier reporter who interviewed him, several stories of experiences he had had during his 35 years in banking, and said that probably one of the biggest thrills he had was when he was threatened with being shot while he was out collecting. He had had no experiences with robberies, and of course had experienced the usual difficulties with balancing.

The Canora Courier
